POR.DRECONTENT:
In my fellowship, I worked with Jean-Michel Morel at Ecole Normale Superieure de Cachan and Ronald Coifman at Yale University. My areas of focus were image interpolation, demosaicking, and applications to medical imaging. I also became a strong supporter of the new journal Image Processing On Line (IPOL). My experience has been fruitful and enjoyable.

During my Ph.D. dissertation, I developed "contour stencils," an idea for estimating image contours for the application of image interpolation. While at ENS Cachan, I succeeded in significantly improving its discretization and a deeper numerical analysis, which was a major goal of my proposal. This resulted in an image interpolation method that is competitive with the state of the art. I successfully extended contour stencils to applications in image demosaicking and atomic force microscopy images. Examples are shown in the attached images.

I became an author and technical team member of a new journal. Image Processing On Line (IPOL, www.ipol.im) is a new journal on image processing hosted by ENS Cachan. IPOL started as an effort by Nicolas Limare and Jean-Michel Morel in response to the serious problem in image processing research that algorithmic details of published methods are often overlooked and the implementation is not disclosed, making it difficult to reproduce results. The IPOL journal is unique in that for every article, source code is included to ensure that its research is reproducible, and all materials are freely available. I believe this is the correct approach to increasing public participation in science and technology.

I published 10 articles in IPOL on topics in image interpolation, demosaicking, and total variation regularization, including several pedagogical articles so that effective methods are accessible to a greater audience. I develop Python and JavaScript code for the web demonstration framework and participate in discussions on technical decisions.

At Yale University, I learned methods for data classification and developed a practical method for segmenting features of interest in medical images. I collaborated with medical researchers on the link between human placenta growth and the presence of an amino acid transporter protein (TAU-T), in which my segmentation approach quantified the presence of immunohistochemically stained TAU-T.

I have continued to collaborate with my doctoral advisor Luminita Vese and her student Melissa Tong, we have published a paper on several methods for 3D MRI image deblurring with a Rician noise model. I am also currently collaborating with biomedical engineering researchers on applying the powerful block matching 3D (BM3D) technique to CT reconstruction.

I developed a software package "tvreg" for C and MATLAB that implements total variation regularized image denoising, deconvolution, and inpainting as well as the Chan–Vese segmentation method. This package is freely distributed on MATLAB Central and Sciweavers with the hope to make total variation regularization techniques more accessible to researchers and practitioners in the field. I published three articles on IPOL about tvreg, with a fourth to appear.

The papers and projects discussed above can be found on my homepage www.getreuer.info. My experience between ENS Cachan and Yale has opened many collaborations and exposed me to new research interests. I plan to continue in these directions beyond this fellowship. I also plan to continue to participate with the IPOL journal and its development.
